title: Worked Solution
text:
To calculate the wavelength of the light emitted by potassium atoms, we can use the energy-wavelength relation:

E $$=$$ $$ rac{hc}{\lambda}$$

Where:
- E is the energy difference $$(4.9$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-19} $$J)$$, $$
$$ $$-$$ $$h$$ $$is$$ $$Planck's$$ $$constant$$ $$(6.626$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-34} $$J·s)$$, $$
$$ $$-$$ $$c$$ $$is$$ $$the$$ $$speed$$ $$of$$ $$light$$ $$(3.00$$ $$	imes$$ $${10}^8$$ m/s)$$, $$
$$ $$-$$ $$\lambda$$ is the wavelength we need to find.

Rearranging the equation to solve for $$\lambda$$: $$
$$ $$
$$ $$\lambda$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{hc}{E}$$

Now, substituting the values:

$$\lambda$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{(6.626$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-34}) $$	imes$$ $$(3.00$$ $$	imes$$ 10**8)}{4.9 $$	imes$$ 10**{-19}}$$

Calculating this:

$$\lambda$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{1.9878$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-25}}{4.9 $$	imes$$ 10**{-19}} $$=$$ $$4.06$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-7} $$\$$, $$	ext{m}$$

Since we need the wavelength in nanometers (nm):

$$\lambda$$ $$=$$ $$4.06$$ $$	imes$$ 10**{-7} $$\$$, $$	ext{m$$} $$	imes$$  rac{10**9 $$\$$, $$	ext{nm}}{1$$ $$\$$, $$	ext{m}$$} $$=$$ $$406$$ $$\$$, $$	ext{nm}$$

Thus, the wavelength of the light emitted is approximately $$406$$ nm.
